dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The idea of Trump's 'collaborative approach' with China is such a fascinating paradox, you know? He assumed his policies would actually help China's growth, but then he also isolated them internationally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The idea of Trump's 'collaborative approach' with China is such a fascinating paradox, you know? He assumed his policies would actually help China's growth, but then he also isolated them internationally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps bombastic, go-it-alone approach was fundamentally flawed. He seems to have assumed that his policies would harm China to the point that it could not effectively compete with the US economically, politically, or militarily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that isolation sent a really clear signal, um, to the rest of the world. But the text argues that, weirdly enough, those policies ended up helping both countries in a way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that isolation sent a really clear signal, um, to the rest of the world. But the text argues that, weirdly enough, those policies ended up helping both countries in a way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumpian policies no doubt damaged China, but they hurt the US, too. His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right—like, it mentions that war is probable between them, but harmony is somehow also certain? That's such a tense balance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right-like, it mentions that war is probable between them, but harmony is somehow also certain? That's such a tense balance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Sino-American rivalry is inevitable, both governments know that war is unthinkable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this part about the WTO—how China raised its tariffs from 40% to 80% before leaving in 2001. They really resisted those global trade rules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this part about the W T O-how China raised its tariffs from forty percent to eighty percent before leaving in two thousand one. They really resisted those global trade rules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Accordingly, China lowered its average tariff rate from 40% in 1992 to 15% by 2000 (and still further subsequently) and removed other trade barriers in order to conform to the WTOs rules, before joining the organization in 2001.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and the US didn't have much luck challenging them there either—lost all its cases at the WTO dispute mechanism. So Trump's shift to bilateral pressure, like the 2018 trade peace, was a huge change in strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and the U S didn't have much luck challenging them there either-lost all its cases at the W T O dispute mechanism. So Trump's shift to bilateral pressure, like the twenty eighteen trade peace, was a huge change in strategy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US took many of its trade grievances with China to the WTO, and won most of its cases. In 2018, Trump launched a trade war.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, the article calls a success, even though it forced China to import less from the US? That part confused me a little—like, how does reducing imports help the US surplus?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, the article calls a success, even though it forced China to import less from the U S? That part confused me a little-like, how does reducing imports help the U S surplus?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Well, economists pointed out that tariffs could artificially inflate that surplus, but it's not exactly sustainable. And then there's the phase one deal in 2020—met all of Trump's demands, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, economists pointed out that tariffs could artificially inflate that surplus, but it's not exactly sustainable. And then there's the phase one deal in twenty twenty-met all of Trump's demands, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US and China signed a phase one trade agreement in January 2020, but it fell far short of meeting Trumps demands. Even the agreed provisions were not fulfilled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But now under Biden, there's talk of undermining the WTO further by rejecting new judges on the Appellate Body. It feels like both sides are still playing with fire, even if trade looks friendly on the surface.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now under Biden, there's talk of undermining the W T O further by rejecting new judges on the Appellate Body. It feels like both sides are still playing with fire, even if trade looks friendly on the surface.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But both countries could begin to reset relations with an agreement to restore the WTOs dispute-settlement role through US approval of new Appellate Body judges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—and with issues like intellectual property or e-commerce, the text suggests ignoring multilateral forums entirely. Just go bilateral.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-and with issues like intellectual property or e-commerce, the text suggests ignoring multilateral forums entirely. Just go bilateral.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And because disputes on issues such as intellectual-property rights and e-commerce can and should be resolved multilaterally, the US should raise these at the WTO instead of making bilateral demands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which might lead to more confrontation, honestly. But if US productivity keeps declining, that could ironically push China and the US into an even more confrontational harmony, if that makes sense?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which might lead to more confrontation, honestly. But if U S productivity keeps declining, that could ironically push China and the U S into an even more confrontational harmony, if that makes sense?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With luck, healthy US productivity growth could then enable the Chinese-American rivalry to proceed along less confrontational lines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does—like a forced cooperation that's always on the edge of breaking down. Not exactly stable, but maybe that's the new normal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does-like a forced cooperation that's always on the edge of breaking down. Not exactly stable, but maybe that's the new normal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Let's hope cooler heads prevail, but I'm not holding my breath.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Let's hope cooler heads prevail, but I'm not holding my breath.

artist_script:
HostA: The idea of Trump's 'collaborative approach' with China is such a fascinating paradox, you know? He assumed his policies would actually help China's growth, but then he also isolated them internationally.
HostB: Yeah, and that isolation sent a really clear signal, um, to the rest of the world. But the text argues that, weirdly enough, those policies ended up helping both countries in a way.
HostA: Right—like, it mentions that war is probable between them, but harmony is somehow also certain? That’s such a tense balance.
HostB: And then there’s this part about the WTO—how China raised its tariffs from 40% to 80% before leaving in 2001. They really resisted those global trade rules.
HostA: Mhm, and the US didn’t have much luck challenging them there either—lost all its cases at the WTO dispute mechanism. So Trump’s shift to bilateral pressure, like the 2018 trade peace, was a huge change in strategy.
HostB: Which, uh, the article calls a success, even though it forced China to import less from the US? That part confused me a little—like, how does reducing imports help the US surplus?
HostA: Well, economists pointed out that tariffs could artificially inflate that surplus, but it’s not exactly sustainable. And then there’s the phase one deal in 2020—met all of Trump’s demands, apparently.
HostB: But now under Biden, there’s talk of undermining the WTO further by rejecting new judges on the Appellate Body. It feels like both sides are still playing with fire, even if trade looks friendly on the surface.
HostA: Exactly—and with issues like intellectual property or e-commerce, the text suggests ignoring multilateral forums entirely. Just go bilateral.
HostB: Which might lead to more confrontation, honestly. But if US productivity keeps declining, that could ironically push China and the US into an even more confrontational harmony, if that makes sense?
HostA: It does—like a forced cooperation that’s always on the edge of breaking down. Not exactly stable, but maybe that’s the new normal.
HostB: For sure. Let’s hope cooler heads prevail, but I’m not holding my breath.
